love swears that she is made of truth,</Line>           <Line number="2">I do believe her, though I know she lies,</Line>           <Line number="3">That she might think me some untutor'd youth,</Line>           <Line number="4">Unskilful in the world's false forgeries.</Line>           <Line number="5">Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young,</Line>           <Line number="6">Although I know my years be past the best,</Line>           <Line number="7">I smiling credit her false-speaking tongue,</Line>           <Line number="8">Outfacing faults in love with love's ill rest.</Line>           <Line number="9">But wherefore says my love that she is young?</Line>           <Line number="10">And wherefore say not I that I am old?</Line>           <Line number="11">O, love's best habit is a soothing tongue,</Line>           <Line number="12">And age, in love, loves not to have years told.</Line>           <Line number="13">Therefore I'll lie with love, and love with me,</Line>           <Line number="14">Since that our faults in love thus smother'd be.</Line>         </PlainText>         <PhoneticText>HN M LF SWRS 0T X IS MT OF TR0 I T BLF HR <PlainText>           <Line number="15">Two loves I have, of comfort and despair,</Line>           <Line number="16">That like two spirits do suggest me still;</Line>           <Line number="17">My better angel is a man right fair,</Line>           <Line number="18">My worser spirit a woman colour'd ill.</Line>           <Line number="19">To win me soon to hell, my female evil</Line>           <Line number="20">Tempteth my better angel from my side,</Line>           <Line number="21">And would corrupt my saint to be a devil,</Line>           <Line number="22">Wooing his purity with her fair pride.</Line>           <Line number="23">And whether that my angel be turn'd fiend,</Line>           <Line number="24">Suspect I may, yet not directly tell:</Line>           <Line number="25">For being both to me, both to each friend,</Line>           <Line number="26">I guess one angel in another's hell;</Line>           <Line number="27">The truth I shall not know, but live in doubt,</Line> number="32">Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment.</Line>           <Line number="33">A woman I forswore; but I will prove,</Line>           <Line number="34">Thou being a goddess, I forswore not thee:</Line>           <Line number="35">My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly love;</Line>           <Line number="36">Thy grace being gain'd cures all disgrace in me.</Line>           <Line number="37">My vow was breath, and breath a vapour is;</Line>           <Line number="38">Then, thou fair sun, that on this earth doth shine,</Line>           <Line number="39">Exhale this vapour vow;     <Line number="44">With young Adonis, lovely, fresh, and green,</Line>           <Line number="45">Did court the lad with many a lovely look,</Line>           <Line number="46">Such looks as none could look but beauty's queen.</Line>           <Line number="47">She told him stories to delight his ear;</Line>           <Line number="48">She showed him favors to allure his eye;</Line>           <Line number="49">To win his heart, she touch'd him here and there,--</Line>           <Line number="50">Touches so soft still conquer chastity.</Line>           <Line number="51">But whether unripe years did want conceit,</Line>           <Line number="52">Or he refused to take her figured proffer,</Line>           <Line number="53">The tender nibbler would not touch the bait,</Line>           <Line number="54">But smile and jest at every gentle offer:</Line>           <Line number="55">Then fell she on her back, fair queen, and toward:</Line>           <Line number="56">He rose and ran away; ah, fool too froward!</Line>         </PlainText>         <PhoneticText>SWT S0R STNK B A BRK W0 YNK ATNS LFL FRX ANT KRN TT KRT 0 LT W0 MN A LFL LK SX LKS AS NN KLT LK BT BTS KN X TLT HM STRS T love?</Line>           <Line number="58">O never faith could hold, if not to beauty vow'd:</Line>           <Line number="59">Though to myself forsworn, to thee I'll constant prove;</Line>           <Line number="60">Those thoughts, to me like oaks, to thee like osiers bow'd.</Line>           <Line number="61">Study his bias leaves, and makes his book thine eyes,</Line>           <Line number="62">Where all those pleasures live that art can comprehend.</Line>           <Line number="63">If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice;</Line>           <Line number="64">Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend;</Line>           <Line number="65">All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;</Line>           <Line number="66">Which is to me some praise, that I thy parts admire:</Line>           <Line number="67">Thine eye Jove's lightning seems, thy voice his dreadful</Line>           <Line number="68">thunder,</Line>           <Line number="69">Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.</Line>           <Line number="70">Celestial as thou art, O do not love that wrong,</Line>           <Line number="71">To sing heaven's <Section>1</Section>         <PlainText>           <Line number="104">If music and sweet poetry agree,</Line>           <Line number="105">As they must needs, the sister and the brother,</Line>           <Line number="106">Then must the love be great 'twixt thee and me,</Line>           <Line number="107">Because thou lovest the one, and I the other.</Line>           <Line number="108">Dowland to thee is dear, whose heavenly touch</Line>           <Line number="109">Upon the lute doth ravish human sense;</Line>           <Line number="110">Spenser to me, whose deep conceit is such</Line>           <Line number="111">As, passing all conceit, needs no defence.</Line>           <Line number="112">Thou lovest to hear the sweet melodious sound</Line>           <Line number="113">That Phoebus' lute, the queen of music, makes;</Line>           <Line number="114">And I in deep delight am chiefly drown'd</Line>           <Line number="115">When as himself to singing he betakes.</Line> <PlainText>           <Line number="118">Fair was the morn when the fair queen of love,</Line>           <Line number="119">[     ]</Line>           <Line number="120">Paler for sorrow than her milk-white dove,</Line>           <Line number="121">For Adon's sake, a youngster proud and wild;</Line>           <Line number="122">Her stand she takes upon a steep-up hill:</Line>           <Line number="123">Anon Adonis comes with horn and hounds;</Line>           <Line number="124">She, silly queen, with more than love's good will,</Line>           <Line number="125">Forbade the boy he should not pass those grounds:</Line>           <Line number="126">'Once,' quoth she, 'did I see a fair sweet youth</Line>           <Line number="127">Here in these brakes deep-wounded with a boar,</Line>           <Line number="128">Deep in the thigh, a spectacle of ruth!</Line>           <Line number="129">See, in my thigh,' quoth she, 'here was the sore.'</Line>           <Line
